pullRequest.body:
This PR defines `LaurentPolynomial.eval₂` and provides basic API for it. This was mentioned unter "future work" in the comments.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ eval₂`
`+ eval₂_C`
`+ eval₂_C_mul_T`
`+ eval₂_C_mul_T_n`
`+ eval₂_C_mul_T_neg_n`
`+ eval₂_T`
`+ eval₂_T_n`
`+ eval₂_T_neg_n`
`+ eval₂_toLaurent`
`+ mk'_eq`
`+ mk'_mul_T`
`+ mk'_one_X`
`+ mk'_one_X_pow`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

The "large-import" label seems to be due to the fact that I changed `Laurent.isLocalization` to use the abbreviation `IsLocalization.Away` and therefore needed to import `RingTheory.Localization.Away.Basic`. This is not strictly needed and can be reverted if necessary.
Two quick comments: (1) The map in question seems more like an `eval` than a `lift`, since you are evaluating a Laurent polynomial at a unit.  (2) Do you really need `S` to be commutative?

`S` needs to be commutative because `IsLocalization.lift` is only defined if all the rings involved are commutative. As for the name, I wasn't sure how to call it either, because it's a "lift of an eval", so I think both names would make sense. The thing with eval is that for standard polynomial rings, there are multiple different variants like `Polynomial.eval` (which goes `R[X] → R`), `Polynomial.eval₂` (`R[X] → S`) as well as `Polynomial.evalRingHom` (`R[X] →+* R`) and `Polynomial.eval₂RingHom` (`R[X] →+* S`). To fit in with that naming convention, I would have to call mine `LaurentPolynomial.eval₂RingHom`, which I didn't like because I don't have the other variants (and it wouldn't really make sense to have the non-RingHom variants, since `IsLocalization.lift` works natively with ring homs).

Admittedly, this is minor point and I would be okay with just calling it `LaurentPolynomial.eval`.
Now that I think about it more, `lift` is fine. I have an `eval` PR under construction for less structured contexts.

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra/Polynomial/Laurent): Lifting maps to ring of Laurent polynomials

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).

The "large-import" label seems to be due to the fact that I changed `Laurent.isLocalization` to use the abbreviation `IsLocalization.Away` and therefore needed to import `RingTheory.Localization.Away.Basic`. This is not strictly needed and can be reverted if necessary.
Two quick comments: (1) The map in question seems more like an `eval` than a `lift`, since you are evaluating a Laurent polynomial at a unit.  (2) Do you really need `S` to be commutative?

`S` needs to be commutative because `IsLocalization.lift` is only defined if all the rings involved are commutative. As for the name, I wasn't sure how to call it either, because it's a "lift of an eval", so I think both names would make sense. The thing with eval is that for standard polynomial rings, there are multiple different variants like `Polynomial.eval` (which goes `R[X] → R`), `Polynomial.eval₂` (`R[X] → S`) as well as `Polynomial.evalRingHom` (`R[X] →+* R`) and `Polynomial.eval₂RingHom` (`R[X] →+* S`). To fit in with that naming convention, I would have to call mine `LaurentPolynomial.eval₂RingHom`, which I didn't like because I don't have the other variants (and it wouldn't really make sense to have the non-RingHom variants, since `IsLocalization.lift` works natively with ring homs).

Admittedly, this is minor point and I would be okay with just calling it `LaurentPolynomial.eval`.
Now that I think about it more, `lift` is fine. I have an `eval` PR under construction for less structured contexts.
